page.title: 13Ecology of Cotswolds (1)
page.content: The Cotswold Way advances for 100 miles along the Cotswold escarpment and passes through Painswick.The route is waymarked with a white spot and arrow beside it.These tend to be fairly easy to follow.Along the Cotswold Way beautiful flowers line the roads and meadows,including orchids,cowslips and bluebells.Some of these cannot be found elsewhere in the country. Our D-Block is one of the most ideal sites for British wildlife,with vast areas of mixed woodland and open common land.This ideal combination of trees and grass makes it excellent wildlife cover. The woods and meadows are abundant with birds of many species.This includes small tits,wrens and woodpeckers both green and red.
